full_text: Peter Lynch pointed out that average investors have advantages over Wall Street experts and can outperform the market by using what they already know. Success comes from understanding the companies you own, not just following the market or economic predictions.
name: Emmet Savage

full_text: He said that there are broadly six categories of stocks:\n\n1. Slow Growers: These are typically large, mature companies with modest earnings growth, usually around 2-4% annually. They often pay high dividends. Examples include utilities like ConEd $ED since 1985: https://t.co/JNnvMYqDVc
name: Emmet Savage

full_text: 2. Stalwarts: These are large, established companies with moderate growth rates, usually between 10-12% per year. They are less risky and provide steady returns. Examples include blue-chip companies like Coca-Cola $KO or Procter & Gamble 👇. $PG https://t.co/lczaKgiR77
name: Emmet Savage

full_text: 3. Fast Growers: These are small, aggressive new enterprises that grow at 20-25% a year. These stocks can provide the highest returns but come with higher risk. Examples include young tech companies or innovative startups.\n\nAhem, $NVDA https://t.co/trfjMqCAKt
name: Emmet Savage

full_text: 4. Cyclicals: These companies' fortunes rise and fall with the economic cycle. They tend to do well during economic expansions and suffer during recessions. Examples include auto manufacturers, airlines, and steel companies.\n\nFord $F https://t.co/Urj8GyfZp1
name: Emmet Savage

full_text: 5. Turnarounds: Cos that are experiencing temporary problems but have the potential to recover. Often overlooked and can offer significant returns if the Co successfully turns around. E.g. companies emerging from bankruptcy or those with new management.\n\nAbercrombie $ANF https://t.co/ndXDd6wqwk
name: Emmet Savage

full_text: 6. Asset Plays: These are Cos that own valuable assets not currently reflected in the stock price. The value might be in real estate, natural resources, patents, or cash. E.g  Cos with significant real estate holdings or hidden assets. \nBrookfield Asset Management $BAM maybe? https://t.co/UmfMxRbx5E

One of my favorite metrics when screening stocks: 

Return on Equity

ROE tells you how effective a company is at using shareholder capital (the money you gave in exchange for stocks) to generate profits.

Return On Equity = Net Income ÷ Shareholder Equity

👇 🧵
name: Emmet Savage

full_text: But high ROE doesn’t have any immediate benefit. The benefit comes from a company with a high ROE rate reinvesting their earnings back into the company. This, in turn, gives the company a high growth rate, which is what you want to see as a shareholder.
name: Emmet Savage

full_text: When researching a company, if you find a CFO bragging about “record earnings” in a year, it’s smart to check their ROE as well. That will tell you not just how much more the company is bringing in, but also whether or not management is playing smart with those funds.
